reviewText:
I love anything to do with this theme and time period, but this game didn't do it for me. I did enjoy the filthy commentator during battle, the music and the way the game is actually set out in building your stable of fighters. That said, everything is at a cost for gold or silver coins. Healing, buying space for new fighters, staff to tend to the fighters etc etc... the list goes on.

The gold and silver you start out with is obviously not very much and you wont get far with it. Sure, you could grind away for a long time if you want, but if you hit the 'Buy Gold Here' button at the top of the screen you will be presented with different packages to purchase coin for real money and speed the progress up. This is where I closed the game down and left it alone. I knew this before installing the game, but I wanted to see how the combat was.

So the combat was OK I suppose. Simple to understand and works for how the game is designed. It's not fast and frantic, but more  like an MMO with cooldowns and timers. Personally I'd have liked something faster, flashy and fluid, but this does actually work quite well. You can time your block (I tried several times and pulled it off a few times) and you can dodge by pressing W or S at a certain time (no obvious sign and I didn't manage it). The main hub has a ton of things going on. It was quite overwhelming at first glance. After looking around after the very basic tutorial, it didn't seem as bad.

I have only played about 30-45 minutes and the main reason I do not recommend this F2P game is because it's a time sink that encourages the purchase of gold with real money. It may be F2P and not P2W, which in theory is true as you apparently only get matched up against people of the same level, but that is just splitting hairs where I come from. This could have been fun with a price tag on it.

reviewText:
Initially, I gave this game a bad review and have come to regret that somewhat.

If you approach this game like an RPG and expect to babysit a character to epicness without risk then this isn't the game for you. However, if you enjoy the challenge of not only raising characters but optimising your gains from risks this game excels.

I started earlier in the week as a free player and found it incredibly frustrating. My gladiators were dying (because gladiators never die right?) I wasn't winning a lot (actually the wins to loss ratio wasn't that bad I was just mismanaging my income and button bashing in fights.) and I was all but ready to give up.


Well... with some perserverence I managed to build my surviving gladiators up, my wins to losses got much better (my two best dudes died though so that was annoying) and I was raking in silver which was awesome. All on a free account.

So I woke up today and bought some gold and purchased some premium gladiators and support staff.

They're not that op which is gratifying, I still have to think about how I fight matches (though I don't always... I'm lazy like that) because while the Gladiator is replaced on death he loses all his accumulated XP. The free replacement of Gladiators isn't that much of a game changer as A) you still don't them to die because of the accumulated XP so playing does not in the least become a no brainer and B) the bonuses they get to XP, Silver and fan rewards are nice but low key enough not to sky rocket you to ascendency! The real asset from the premium gladiators has been that I don't need to waste silver constantly buying new meat for the grinder. But it's not THAT pronounced.

I would however highly recommend buying premium Gladiators just on the replacement you get if they die. But you can play just fine without them.

Now this is not an RPG really, what it is, is a roguelike gladiator sim wherein the actual fightin in the arena is only maybe two thirds of the game.

As long as you go into the game with the understanding that it IS hard and that your men WILL die you'll be fine and have a great time.

My only complaints are a) the controls sometimes go unresponsive but that might be a fault my end I haven't bothered playing other games this week to test it and B) I can't select to automatically go against the computer. I know it's an mmo... but I want easy XP :P

I cannot reccomend this game. Anyone remotely interested in playing it better wait a few months, will need that ammount of time to fix what's wrong with it. And trust me, there's a lot that needs fixing.

I started playing this about a month ago, quit after trying to be the bigger man and not be bothered with the bugs and latency issues(only to quit), to come back after rewatching Spartacus and replaying Shadow of Rome. And quite frankly, despite their attempts at trying to fix it, it might have actually gotten worse.

The latency is the big bad guy in this negative review. After nearly 2 months after release it still rears its ugly head and makes the process of trying to play it a near nightmare. If you're not experiencing frequent framerate drops in multiplayer, you'll love flying all over the place versus bots. Used to be that despite having bad matches against other people, with latency downright f**king you in the ♥♥♥ at the most inopportune of moments, you'd at least be able to make some form of progress by farming AI. Not nearly as fun, but it worked. Now I'd be lucky if I manage to beat the AI with the 3 second delays I keep getting on my actions, whether it's attacking or just moving around.

I'll be uninstalling this sucker again until a later date, hoping that the issues present will be addressed, because despite all: it is a fun game to play. It just isn't right now.

Did you really come down here to get informed? All you want is to have your suspicions confirmed.

Pay To Win
I can confirm. Yes, it's a complete P2W fest. Non premium gladiators and staff are ultimately temporary. Gladiators die, and staff leaves. Only paid stuff remains - but it's not enough. The paid stuff will eventually become useless as well, unless you continue paying for more expensive and higher tier staff/gladiators. That means you could spend $40 at the start of the game, just to be forced to spend even more some hours later, as your low tier premium gladiators won't be enough. The amount of money you need to spend keeps exponentially expanding - if you had any experience with this kind of mechanic you would walk away right now.

But you're still reading, so I this is just for you:

It's a C game with a 5xAAA pricetag. Only way to have any fun with the game is to keep pumping exorbitant amounts of cash into it. In theory it's possible to earn the premium currency in-game. But where you gain a few dozen/hour, at most - the game requires tens of thousands. It reminds me of those incredibly crappy F2P shooters with timed gear - pay $25 to have some assault rifle for 1 month. Or spend 50 in-game hours to be able to buy the same weapon with non premium currency, for 1 week.


Additional note: 0.2 hrs is enough to find out how the flow of the game is going to go, what insane amounts of cash you will need to spend to have some basic fun, or worse, what insane amounts of frustration you will need to get through if you don't wish to pay.

reviewText:
Quite a decent game but it does have its flaws. Which i hope can be fixed with time. The game has potential.

The good:
1. Manage your own house and your gladiators
2. Decent graphics that will run on low end machines
3. Fun IF you like the spartacus TV series or gladiators in general.
4. A unique game. There aren't many in this genre which is a shame.
5. Good tutorial

The bad:
1. Not enough blood and gore for a gladiator game. Let me cut of limbs and cause wounds that you can see on the gladiator (slice marks and puncture wounds) and let those leave scars so your gladiator looks battle hardened.

2. Some pay to win elements in the gold armor being better then the normal silver armor of the same tier (except tier 10)

3. The fights are boring and lackluster. Hit, block, use some skills, hit block etc. Would be more fun IF it were more dynamic and action combat based and not the current boring animations.

4. Waiting times for healing and stamina regain makes it feel like a mobile game.
